{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3175394,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-28T17:00:25.782Z","cooked":"

We’ve been having problems gripping cones and would like to use a higher pressure on the pneumatic cylinder than we use for cube – the concern is that the pressure for the cone might pop the cube, and we don’t want to do that.

One option is to use a 3-port solenoid – connect one pressure to the input and another pressure into the exhaust, then pipe the output of that solenoid into the input of the actual solenoid that controls the cylinder. But, that’s a non-standard use. It doesn’t break the rule about connecting outputs together (since we’re connecting an output to an input), but I don’t know if the description of the solenoid as “directional” means that we can’t do this. (I know that there are “balanced” solenoids, but the ones I found all have NPSF connections, which aren’t permitted per R804(C)).

Will it work?

I’m having trouble picturing that set up, but couldn’t this setup “trap” air in a branch, even when the vent valve is open?

Thought about it, but don’t think so. Every line is either (a) connected through a pressure regulator to the master relief valve, or (b) to a vent.

168002665890135725712013679251421920×1080 116 KB

The one oddity is that if you switch from 60psi to 30, you get 60psi of pressure in your 30psi line until the pressure regulator vents it.

I think this is the more “correct” implementation

Dual-pressure pneumatic actuation Pneumatics
You can replace the backwards valve with just a shuttle valve and a two position (3 port) valve with default outlet plugged. Plumb the higher pressure to the valve then the outlet to the shuttle valve. Plumb low pressure to shuttle valve. Plumb outlet of shuttle valve to other solenoid. Now you can turn the high pressure on/off, and the shuttle valve directs the higher pressure to the control solenoid. edit: We used this general setup to save some additional air for climbing in seperate tanks…
